page.title: 7.15.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will be introduced to quadratic expressions in vertex form and learn that this form allows us to easily see where the vertex of a graph is located.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Recognize the "vertex form" of a quadratic equation.
  • Relate the numbers in the vertex form of a quadratic equation to its graph.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.15.1: Analyzing Two Sets of Equations
  • 7.15.2: The Vertex Form
    • 7.15.2: Self Check
    • 7.15.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.15.3: The Coordinates of the Vertex
    • 7.15.3: Self Check
    • 7.15.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.15.4: The Graph of a Function in Vertex Form

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.15.5: Practice
  • 7.15.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.15.1: Analyzing Two Sets of Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Set 1:

\(f(x)=x^2+4x\)

\(g(x)=x(x+4)\)

\(h(x)=(x+2)^2−4\)

Set 2:

\(p(x)=-x^2+6x−5\)

\(q(x)=(5−x)(x−1)\)

\(r(x)=-1(x−3)^2+4\)


  1. After observing the two sets, what do you notice? 

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Things you notice:

  • Each set has three equations.
  • Each equation has the output in function notation on the left side of the equal sign, and an expression on the right side.
  • The expressions are in standard form, factored form, and one other form.
  • The equations in standard and factored form are equivalent.

  1. After observing the two sets, what do you wonder? 

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Things you may wonder:

  • Why are the equations in each set grouped together?
  • In each set, is the expression in the last equation written in a particular form? What is it called?
  • In each set, is the expression in the last equation equivalent to the other two?

page.title: 7.15.2: The Vertex Form
page.contents:
Activity

Here are two sets of equations for quadratic functions you saw earlier. In each set, the expressions that define the output are equivalent. In other words, all the equations in Set 1 define the same function. The same is true for Set 2: all the equations define the same function but they are just written in different forms.

Set 1:

\(f(x)=x^2+4x\)

\(g(x)=x(x+4)\)

\(h(x)=(x+2)^2−4\)

Set 2:

\(p(x)=-x^2+6x−5\)

\(q(x)=(5−x)(x−1)\)

\(r(x)=-1(x−3)^2+4\)

The expression that defines \(h\) is written in vertex form. We can show that it is equivalent to the expression defining \(f\) by expanding and simplifying the expression:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}(x+2)2-4&=&(x+2)(x+2)-4\\&=&x2+2x+2x+4-4\\&=&x2+4x,\;\mathrm{which}\;\mathrm{is}\;f(x)\end{array}\)

If this simplified expression is factored, then we arrive at the expression that defines function \(g\): \(x^2+4x=x(x+4)\). The expression that defines \(g\) is written in factored form. The simplified expression that defines function \(f\) is written in standard form.


  1. Show that the expressions defining \(r\) and \(p\) are equivalent.

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Expanding and simplifying function \(r\), \(-1(x−3)^2+4 gives -1(x^2−6x+9)+4\), which equals \(-x^2+6x−9+4\) or \(-x^2+6x−5\).


For questions 2–3, examine the graphs representing the quadratic functions.

  1. Examine the graph of the function \(h\).

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(h\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -2

The correct answer is -2.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(h\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -4

The correct answer is -4.

  1. Examine the graph of the function \(r\).

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(r\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 3

The correct answer is 3.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(r\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 4

The correct answer is 4.


  1. Why do you think expressions such as those defining \(h\) and \(r\) are said to be written in vertex form?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The numbers in vertex form seem to give the coordinates of the vertex of the graph. When a positive number is added to the \(x\) in the parentheses, the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex seems to be negative—which is the opposite of that number. When a number is subtracted from \(x\), the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex seems to be positive—which is the opposite of what it looks like.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to expand the binomial by multiplying \((x - 3)(x - 3)\). The answer is \(y=x^2-6x\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to expand the binomial by multiplying \((x - 3)(x - 3)\). The answer is \(y=x^2-6x\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x - 3)(x - 3)\) then subtract 9.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to expand the binomial by multiplying by multiplying \((x - 3)(x - 3)\). Watch the signs. For the middle terms \(-3x + -3x = -6x\). The answer is \(y=x^2-6x\).

page.title: 7.15.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Equivalent Forms of Quadratics

Quadratics can be written in different equivalent forms:

  • Standard form: \(y=ax^2+bx+c\)
  • Factored form: \(y = (x + a)(x + b)\)
  • Vertex form: \(y=a(x-h)^2+k\)

Example

Write \(y=(x+2)^2-9\) in standard and factored forms.

Here is how to find the equivalent standard form:

Step 1
Expand the vertex form to multiply the binomials.
\(y=(x+2)(x+2)-9\)

Step 2
Multiply the binomials.
\(y=x^2+2x+2x+4-9\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(y=x^2+4x-5\)

Here is how to find the factored form:

Step 1
From the standard form, find the factors of the trinomial expression \(y=x^2+4x-5\).

Step 2
Examine the trinomial expression.
\(x^2+4x-5\)

Step 3
Factor the trinomial.
\((x + 5)(x - 1)\)

The factored form is \(y = (x + 5)(x - 1)\).

Try It: Equivalent Forms of Quadratics


Find the equation in standard form that is equivalent to \(y=(x-2)^2+4\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the equivalent standard form:

Step 1
Expand the vertex form to multiply the binomials.
\(y=(x-2)(x-2)+4\)

Step 2
Multiply the binomials.
\(y=x^2-2x-2x+4 + 4\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(y=x^2-4x+8\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.15.3: The Coordinates of the Vertex
page.contents:
Activity


  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph \(y=x^2\). Then, add different numbers to \(x\) before it is squared (for example, \(y=(x+4)^2\), \(y=(x−3)^2\)) and observe how the graph changes.

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Adding a number to \(x\) moves the graph to the left. Subtracting a number (or adding a negative number) moves the graph to the right. The vertex stays on the \(x\)-axis.


  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph \(y=(x−1)^2\). Then, experiment with each of the following changes to the function and see how they affect the graph and the vertex.
  1. Add different constant terms to \((x−1)^2\) (for example: \(y=(x−1)^2+5\), \(y=(x−1)^2−9)\).


Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Adding a constant term moves it up and subtracting moves it down. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex doesn't change.


  1. Multiplying \((x−1)^2\) by different coefficients (for example: \(y=3(x−1)^2\), \(y=-2(x−1)^2\), \(y=0.5(x−1)^2\).

Write down your answer. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Multiplying the squared term by a number doesn't change the vertex, but it changes the opening of the graph to "wider" or "narrower," or changes the direction of the graph to open upward or downward.


  1. Without graphing, find the coordinates of the vertex of \(y=(x+10)^2\) and determine if it opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is -10.

The correct answer is -10. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is -10.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 0.

The correct answer is 0. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 0.

  1. Does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up. The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1).


Select the solution button to see the solutions to question 3 organized into a table.

Compare your Answer:

Equation

Coordinates of vertex

Graph opens up or down?

\(y=(x+10)^2\)

\((-10, 0)\)

Up

  1. Without graphing, find the coordinates of the vertex of \(y=(x−4)^2+8\) and determine if it opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 4.

The correct answer is 4. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 4.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 8.

The correct answer is 8. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 8.

  1. Does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up. The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1).


Select the solution button to see the solutions to questions 3–4 organized into a table.

What patterns do you notice? Can you use those ideas to find the vertices for the next equation? What do you know about whether it will open up or down?

  1. Without graphing, find the coordinates of the vertex of \(y=-(x−4)^2+8\) and determine if it opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 4.

The correct answer is 4. The v-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 4.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 8.

The correct answer is 8. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 8.

  1. Does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient (-1).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Down. The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient (-1).


Select the solution button to see the solutions to questions 3–5 organized into a table

  1. The next equation, \(y=x^2−7\), looks a little different from the previous ones. Can you use what you’ve learned to find the coordinates of its vertex and determine if it opens up or down.
    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 0.

The correct answer is 0. The v-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is 0.

    1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is -7.

The correct answer is -7. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is -7.

  1. Does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \((1)\).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up.The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \((1)\).

Select the solution button to see the solutions to questions 3–6 organized into a table

  1. Are the patterns you noticed still happening? See if you can apply those patterns to the following equations.
  1. For the equation \(y=\frac{1}{2}(x+3)^2−5\), what is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(–3\).

The correct answer is \(–3\). The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(–3\).

  1. For the equation \(y=\frac{1}{2}(x+3)^2−5\), what is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(-5\).

The correct answer is \(n\). The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(-5\).

  1. For the equation \(y=\frac{1}{2}(x+3)^2−5\), does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \(\frac{1}{2})\).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up.The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \(\frac{1}{2})\).

  1. For the equation \(y=-(x+100)^2+50\), what is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(–100\).

The correct answer is \(–100\). The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(–100\).

  1. For the equation \(y=-(x+100)^2+50\), what is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(50\).

The correct answer is \(n\). The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(50\).

  1. For the equation \(y=-(x+100)^2+50\), does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient \((-1)\)..

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up. The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient \((-1)\).

The table now has all the equations from questions 3–7, plus an additional row. Use this information to answer question 8. Do the patterns you noticed help you fill in the last row?


  1. Use the completed rows of the table to hypothesize about the coordinates of the vertex of the equation in the last row, and whether the parabola opens up or down.
  1. For the equation \(y=a(x+m)^2+n\), what is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is –\(m\).

The correct answer is –\(m\). The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is –\(m\).

  1. For the equation \(y=a(x+m)^2+n\), what is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(n\).

The correct answer is \(n\). The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this equation is \(n\).

  1. For the equation \(y=a(x+m)a^2+n\), can you determine if the graph opens up or down with the information you are given?

Correct! No, because the direction of opening depends on whether \(a\) is positive or negative.

Incorrect. No, because the direction of opening depends on whether \(a\) is positive or negative.

Extending Your Thinking

Are you ready for more?

Examine the graph below, then use it to answer questions 1–3.

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this graph?

    Answer: 3
  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this graph?

    Answer: -4
  1. Which quadratic equation best fits the function in the graph?

    Answer: \(y=2(x−3)^2−4\). The equation \(y=(x−3)^2−4\) has the vertex at \((3,-4)\). The graph shown has a \(y\)-intercept at (0,14) which doesn't work for the equation \(y=(x−3)^2−4\). The equation \(y=2(x−3)^2−4\) appears to fit. When \(x=0\) the \(y\)-value is \(2(0−3)^2−4=14\).

Video: Learning About the Vertex Form of a Quadratic

Watch the following video to learn more about the vertex form of a quadratic.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 3 does not cause the parabola’s vertex to shift. The correct answer is ((2, -5)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The parabola’s vertex shifts right 2 and down 5 so the vertex is at \((2, -5)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Watch the signs. The parabola’s vertex shifts right 2 and down 5. The correct answer is \((2, -5)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Watch the signs. How does subtracting 5 affect the graph? The vertex shifts down 5. The answer is \((2, -5)\).

page.title: 7.15.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Vertex Form

The vertex form of a quadratic is below:

Notice that the value of \(h\) is the opposite of what it is in the parenthesis. This seems odd: when we add \(k\), the vertex of the parabola moves up \(k\) units. But when we subtract \(h\) within the squared term, the vertex of the parabola moves right \(h\) units, not left.

Let’s explore why. We know the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is \(y = k\). To find that using this equation, we need to know where \(a(x-h)^2\) is zero, because that will make \(y=k\). Set \(a(x-h)^2=0\) . This happens when \(x-h=0\), which is when \(x=h\). That means \(h\) is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Example

Find the vertex of \(y=3(x-4)^2-2\).

The parabola of the quadratic will shift right 4 (remember this horizontal shift is counterintuitive and translates in the opposite direction of what the expression “looks like”) and down 2.

So, the vertex is at \((4, -2)\).

Try It: Using Vertex Form


Find the vertex of \(y= (x-2)^2+5\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the vertex:

The quadratic shifts to the right 2 and up 5. The vertex is at \((2, 5)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.15.4: The Graph of a Function in Vertex Form
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Launch

Since this activity was designed to be completed without technology, ask students to put away any devices.

Student Activity

Answer questions 1–3 about the function \(f\), given by \(f(x)=(x+3)^2−1\).

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(f\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -3

The correct answer is -3.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(f\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -3

The correct answer is -3.

  1. Does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \((1)\).

Incorrect. The correct answer is Up. The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient \((1)\).

page.title: 7.15.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select three quadratic expressions written in vertex form.

Correct! \(y=(x-2)^2 + 1, y=x^2 - 4, y=(x-4)^2 + 6\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.14.2–7.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(y=(x-2)^2 + 1, y=x^2 - 4, y=(x-4)^2 + 6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Examine the following two equations and use them to answer questions 2–5. One defines function \(m\) and the other defines function \(p\).

  • \(m(x)=x(x+6)\)
  • \(p(x)=(x+3)^2−9\)
  1. How do you know that the expressions defining \(m\) and \(p\) are equivalent?

Correct! Both expressions are equal to \(x^2+6x\). \((x+3)^2−9=(x+3)(x+3)−9=x^2+3x+3x+9−9=x^2+6x\) and \(x(x+6)=x^2+6x\).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.14.2 and 7.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Both expressions are equal to \(x^2+6x\). \((x+3)^2−9=(x+3)(x+3)−9=x^2+3x+3x+9−9=x^2+6x\) and \(x(x+6)=x^2+6x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Recall \(m(x)=x(x+6)\) and \(p(x)=(x+3)^2−9\). What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(m\)? 

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -3.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -3. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -3.

  1. Recall \(m(x)=x(x+6)\) and \(p(x)=(x+3)^2−9\). What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of \(m\)? 

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -9.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.14.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -9. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -9.

  1. Recall \(m(x)=x(x+6)\) and \(p(x)=(x+3)^2−9\). What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of \(p\)? 

Correct! (0,0) and (-6,0) The graphs of \(m\) and \(p\) are the same. The zeros of \(m\) are 0 and -6, which give the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is:(0,0) and (-6,0). The graphs of \(m\) and \(p\) are the same. The zeros of \(m\) are 0 and -6, which give the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 6–11, enter the coordinates of the vertex of the graph that represents the equation.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=(x-3)^2 + 5\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 3.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 3.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 5.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=(x+7)^2 + 3\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -7.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -7. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -7.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 3.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 3.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=(x-4)^2\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 4.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 4.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2 - 1\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=2(x+1)^2-5\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -5. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

  1. Find the coordinates of the vertex for the equation \(y=-2(x+1)^2-5\).
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.15.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -5. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

For questions 12–14, answer the questions about the \(x\)- and \(y\)-coordinates of the vertex, and whether the function opens up or down.

  1. For function \(f(x)=(x-4)^2-5\), find the coordinates of the vertex and determine if the function opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 4.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 4. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 4.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -5. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -5.

  1. For the function \(f(x)=(x-4)^2-5\), does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Up. The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (1). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For function \(g(x)=-x^2+5\), find the coordinates of the vertex and determine if the function opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 0. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 0.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 5.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 5. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is 5.

  1. For the function \(g(x)=-x^2+5\), does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient (-1).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Down. The graph opens downward. The squared term has a negative coefficient (-1). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For function \(h(x)=2(x+1)^2-4\), find the coordinates of the vertex and determine if the function opens up or down.
  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -1.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -4.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -4. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of this function is -4.

  1. For the function \(h(x)=2(x+1)^2-4\), does the graph open up or down?

Correct! The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (2).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.15.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Up. The graph opens upward. The squared term has a positive coefficient (2). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.15.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Recognize the "vertex form" of a quadratic equation.
  • Relate the numbers in the vertex form of a quadratic equation to its graph.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.15.1: Analyzing Two Sets of Equations
    • In this activity, you looked at equations in different forms and compared and contrasted them.
  • 7.15.2: The Vertex Form
    • In this activity, you explored the different forms from 7.15.1 and proved that the different forms, factored, standard, and vertex, are equivalent.
    • 7.15.2: Self Check
    • 7.15.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.15.3: The Coordinates of the Vertex
    • In this activity, you used graphing technology to explore how changing the numbers, or parameters, in the vertex form affected the graph of a quadratic.
    • 7.15.3: Self Check
    • 7.15.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.15.4: The Graph of a Function in Vertex Form
    • In this activity, you examined a quadratic function in vertex form and identified the vertex and if the graph of the function opens up or down.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.15.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
